1864 |website = [http://ltgov.nv.gov/ Office of the Lieutenant Governor] }} The '''Nevada Lieutenant Governor''' is an elected office in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Nevada]]. The Nevada Lieutenant Governor is based in [[Carson City, Nevada]] and elected for 4 year terms. The 33rd and current Lt. Governor for the 2007-2011 term is [[Brian Krolicki]]. See [[List of Governors of Nevada]] for list of Lieutenant Governors. ==Living former Lt. governors== {{As of|2007|1|20}}, nine former Lt. governors were alive. The oldest living Lt. governor is [[Paul Laxalt]] (1963–1967, born 1922). The most recent Lt. governor to die was [[Myron E. Leavitt]] (1979–1983), on January 9, 2004. {| class="wikitable" !Lt. Governor!!Lt. Gubernatorial term!!Date of birth |- |[[Paul Laxalt]] |1963–1967 |{{birth date and age|1922|8|2}} |- |[[Edward Fike]] |1967–1971 |{{birth date and age|1925|3|11}} |- |[[Harry Reid]] |1971–1975 |{{birth date and age|1939|12|2}} |- |[[Robert E. Rose]] |1975–1979 |{{birth date and age|1939|10|7}} |- |[[Bob Cashell]] |1983–1987 |{{birth date and age|1938|4|22}} |- |[[Bob Miller (Nevada governor)|Bob Miller]] |1987–1989 |{{birth date and age|1945|3|30}} |- |[[Sue Wagner]] |1991–1995 |{{birth date and age|1940|1|6}} |- |[[Lonnie Hammargren]] |1995–1999 |{{birth date and age|1937|12|25}} |- |[[Lorraine Hunt]] |1999–2007 |{{birth date and age|1939|3|11}} |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://ltgov.nv.gov/ Nevada Lieutenant Governor] {{Current U.S. Lieutenant Governors}} [[Category:Lieutenant Governors of Nevada| ]] [[Category:Carson City, Nevada]]
